response.answer_text: Yes, if I had to make a determination about who the last President I would consider to be “great” was, it was Ronald Reagan. Reagan was exactly the right man at the right time, and he accomplished a great deal of what he set out to do, even though he was fighting a Democratic Congress the whole time. Winning the Cold War and ushering in a very long period of prosperity for the country, along with uniting it more than anyone had in a long time, are all testaments to how well he did. When he died, the assemblage of world leaders at his funeral was on a level not seen since King Edward VII in 1910. There is a reason for this. Ronald Reagan was, and is, a giant of history. We have had two “good” Presidents since Reagan, those being George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton. Bush 41, as I’ve written before, was defeated in his bid for a second term because the challenges that confronted him in 1992 were not ones that were his strong suit as a national leader. He was a heavyweight champion of foreign affairs, but not so much on domestic policy—and facing an economic recession, he faced the perfect candidate to beat him in Clinton. The last great President prior to Reagan was Harry S. Truman. John Cate's answer to Is the conservative era that started with the election of Ronald Reagan over? (Covers both Reagan and Bush 41.)
